Shares of Aspen Insurance Holdings Ltd. AHL, -0.05% surged 3.4% in premarket trade Tuesday, after the insurance company announced overnight an agreement to be acquired by private-equity company Apollo Global Management LLC in a cash deal valued at about $2.6 billion.

Through Monday, Aspen's stock had lost 1.2% year to date, while the SPDR S&P Insurance ETF KIE, -1.31% had advanced 4.9%, Apollo shares had tacked on 3.7% and the S&P 500 SPX, -2.33% had rallied 8.4%.
Under terms of the deal, Apollo will pay $42.75 for each Aspen share outstanding, which is 6.6% above Monday's closing price of $40.10.
The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2019.
Apollo's stock was still inactive in premarket trade.
